moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4: introducing the Italian Party, with an early attack on f7... usually follows Bc5, c3 (preparing d4), Nf6; after Ng5, 0-0, so White usually continues with d4...
moves.4... d5 5. exd5 Na5: another option is Nxd5, Nxf7!? (although d4! is much stronger), Kxf7, Qf3+, usually leading to very sharp play from both sides...
moves.6. Bb5+ c6 7. dxc6 bxc6 8. Qf3: the Blackburne Variation: the simple clue here is cxb6?, Qxa8... best reply here is probably Rb8, forcing Bd3 or even Be2; this last move - originally from Steinitz, followed by Nh3!? - was brought into tournament practice again by Kasparov... Black can also play directly Qd5, Be2 (Bd3, Qxf3, gxf3, Nd5!), e4, Qg3, h6, Nh3, g5...
moves.8... Be7: not too accurate: this will at least cost a pawn; against this opponent, I considered this no small feat...
moves.9. Bxc6+ Nxc6 10. Qxc6+ Bd7 11. Qc4: the other option was Qf3, Rc8, Nc3, Bc6, Qg3, Nh5, Qxe5, f6, Qe2... not very cosy for the Queen...
moves.11... O-O 12. Nc3 Rc8 13. Qe2 h6 14. Nge: better than Nf3, e4, Nxe4, Nxe4, Qxe4, Bb5...
moves.14... Nxe4 15. Qxe4 Bc6 16. Qe2: played in error: I was considering Qf5, Bxg2, Rg1, but could find nothing after Bb7... best here is Qe3, Bc5/Bg5, Qh3...
moves.16... Bxg2 17. Rg1 Bb7 18. d3 Qb6 19. Bd: although still a pawn ahead, White is getting in trouble...
moves.19... Bh4: I was calculating on Qf6, Qh5, Kh8, Rg3, Bc5, 0-0-0, Bd4... this move was stronger, than I suspected...
moves.20. Qe3 Qf6: donating another pawn; I was in no position to argue...
moves.21. Qxa7 Bf3: after Rfe8, Qe3; this prohibits long castling...
moves.22. Qe3 Kh8: no use is Bg5, Rxg5, hxg5, Qxg5, Qb6, Qf5, e4, Nd5...
moves.23. a4: bringing another pawn in the mixture...
moves.23... Rc6: according to GK analysis, this is a mistake; I am not so sure... this pawn will not make the difference...
moves.27. Ne4: the only way to disarm Bf3, in order to reach a8...
moves.27... Bxe4 28. dxe4 Qc6: most certainly not the best move; that would be Ra8... but White has to react; it is too soon for Rg4...
moves.29... Ra8 30. Rg4: I saw nothing after Qd5, Qc8; this holds more initiative...
moves.30... Be7: Bf6 is somewhat better; no good is Bg5, Bxg5, hxg5, Kf1, Rxc2, Rg3, Qc8, Qd5... somehow, Black can afford not playing the best moves...
moves.31. Qd5 Rxc2: again, not the best; Qc8, Rg3 holds more initiative...
moves.32. Qxc6 Rxc6 33. Be3 Bc5 34. Rg3 Bxe3 3: at this point, Black offered a draw; which I declined for no particular reason... apart from the fact, that I saw no longer a way to win this for Black...
moves.37. Ke2: White needs to find a way to penetrate Blacks' Kings' wing... Ra6, Kf8, h4, will not work...
moves.37... f6 38. Kf3 Kf7 39. Kg4 Rb7 40. h4: best here is Re5, Ra5, Re7, but White cannot profit...
moves.45. Ra3a6 Rd7 46. Ra1a5 Rb7 47. Kf4 Rb4: by now, it was dawning on me; Rb7 would always guarantee a draw...
moves.49. Rdd6 g5+ 50. Kf5 gxh4: or Rb5+, Rd5, Rxd5+, exd5, gxh4...
moves.51. Rdxf6+ Kg7 52. Rfg6+ Kh7 53. Rgh6+ K: after Rag6+, Rg7, Rxg7+, Kxg7, Rxh5, Rxa7, Rxh4, White is also a pawn ahead, but after Re7, e5, Kf7, there is no way to win for White... all theory...
moves.54... Raxa7 55. Rxa7 Rxa7 56. Rxh4 Ra6 5: of course meaning to play Rh7+, Ke8, to drive the Black King out of opposition, only to realize that e5 can never enter the sixth row, due to eternal checks by the Black rook; instead, I managed to produce this losing blunder... lucky for me, this opponent was courteous enough to accept a draw...
